summary: influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 in 2009 caused a pandemic. since then it has become a seasonal influenza virus. symptoms range from mild to severe illness, which might be fatal. influenza viruses are single-stranded RNA viruses that belong to the Orthomyxoviridae family. influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 emerged in 2009 causing a global influenza pandemic. only influenza A and B viruses cause epidemics in humans. the public health department at the Ministry of Health in Saudi Arabia established its first case-based Influenza surveillance system. healthcare facilities, including the private sector, were required to test all suspected cases and report the clinical details of all confirmed cases using unified data collection forms. a total of 113 588 suspected influenza cases were reported in 2010. the total of confirmed cases was 17 094 (15.1%) (Table 1). the highest number of confirmed cases were reported in the year 2010 followed by 2015. the fewest were reported in the year 2013. the majority of cases were suspected cases based on the case definition. influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 activity takes place in Saudi Arabia between week 42 of one year and week 11 of the next Gregorian year. highest number of confirmed cases (1080, 6.3%) were reported in epidemio-logical week 46 of the year 2015. less than 100 cases per week were reported between week 12 and 39. the least affected age group were those aged 5–14 years. there was a slight gradual age shifting over time towards elders. there was a slight gradual age shifting over time towards elders. influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 over these 7 years affected all age groups. the most affected were those aged 30–59 years (38%) and 12–29 years (20%) the least affected age group were those aged 5–14 years. report of influenza surveillance was the first to be instituted in response to the 2009 influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 pandemic in Saudi Arabia. previous studies only concentrated on the few hundred cases first discovered before establishing the surveillance
